Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Fostering integration of computational practices into physics courses - A local communities approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Studies have for a long time documented the need to introduce computational physics into the undergraduate curriculum. The future workforce needs to be computationally competent-in thinking as well as in skills and practice. This project is a response to the need and proposes exploration into a new change model using a research-based Framework. The Framework - a structure and a research strategy for introducing computation into undergraduate physics was born in 2006 and developed by the Partnership for Integration of Computation into Undergraduate Physics (PICUP).
The purpose of this collaborative research exploration is to design and test an adaptation of the Framework that is effective and sustainable and that can be scaled up by replication. It is a proof of concept study centered on this project's attempt at significant curricular reform through faculty development starting at the grass roots. The research-based PICUP Framework will be used in a local approach at a sectional meeting of the American Association of Physics Teachers (AAPT) followed by extensive collaborative development work among participating faculty. Research-based faculty development will be implemented at regional sites and will be scaled up by replication in any of the 47 AAPT sections. Central to the evaluation plan is assessing how this novel approach helps a computational community to develop. An experienced evaluator is developing metrics to measure progress.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Jobs and graduate education in STEM fields require that students be adept at using computation as a tool to solve scientific and technical problems. Integrating computation into the undergraduate curriculum is a challenge in fields such as Physics where the curriculum is not only well established but also extensive. This project sought to (1) promote the integration of computation into the Physics undergraduate curriculum and (2) give faculty resources and guidance in order to successfully integrate computation into their courses. In order to achieve these goals, we conducted eight faculty development workshops around the country and recruited a faculty member in each region to act as coordinator of a local community where participants could offer each other guidance and support. Approximately 120 faculty members at over 60 colleges and universities were impacted by this project.  As a result of the project, we have designed workshops in several formats that can be used for continuing faculty development to enhance the integration of computational work in undergraduate physics courses. We have also studied issues encountered in our efforts to facilitate and sustain faculty engagement after each workshop was over. This study highlighted both opportunities and difficulties attributable specifically to the local community context of this project. But our findings are also likely applicable to any faculty development projects that aim to sustain participants’ continuing engagement in integrating into their courses the new techniques they learn in those faculty development workshops.
